content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: In some languages, this is going to be headache...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash. I always find these number spiral clashes hard, but the author's solution is really intuitive and quite simple. Using this approach, it's quite easy to solve in 5 minutes.
I think lots of clashers will fail to find a good solution in time, but you can't win 'em all!

Nice clash. I always find these number spiral clashes hard, but your solution is really intuitive and quite simple. I had previously thought that you needed to do a recursive solution to be able to solve these quickly (and I struggle with coding recursive solutions under time pressure).

The only issue I have is that it's enabled for Reverse, but there's only 4 test cases. I think it's always better to have more test cases for Reverse mode, so that clashers can really understand what to expect in the validators. Here the important thing is that [[n]] is always odd, but with only 4 test cases it might not be clear that that is true and a clasher might waste time trying to figure out what their code should do for even [[n]].
Overall, it looks great. About the sample solution, if the for loop goes up to (N**2)+1, is Line 15 no longer needed?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Relatively simple although can be a bit tedious depending on the approach chosen.

I'm sure there are much shorter ways than the solution I went for!

After solving it, I found this discussion which has several solutions to a related problem (the spiral goes from centre outwards instead of from out inwards):
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36834505/creating-a-spiral-array-in-python
Yes, that's correct. Originally something else was meant to go in the middle square and I didn't bother changing that line XD

Hello, I think that it is already fairly clear from the 4 odd test cases that n is supposed to be odd. Even if I add a fifth or sixth odd test case someone might still waste time solving it for even n. 

What I could do instead is organize the test cases as 3, 5, 7, 1 to make it more obvious what's going on (I don't want the first test case to be 1 since that is shown to fastest/shortest players). What do you think?
And that's the reason why you approved the clash?

In Python it takes a few lines of code, but in Bash for example no idea how to do it.
If you prefer, we can remove the approval?
It's ok to keep your approval. I was just curious so I asked.

Often I get these headaches solving Clash of Code puzzles. When I saw the solution for this one, all of the sudden it became clear why.
Except for that, this Number Spiral exercise is amazing. For real developers, this kind of challenges is perfectly suited.
As far as I'm concerned, I'm only trying to learn a bit of Bash (and I get stuck like all the time)

Understood.

I mean, in the approval dialog box, you're asked to type in why you approve a contribution. So, if one states that it'd be a good chance to solve a contribution in a particular language, it sounds all right.

But if one states it'd be a headache instead of a good chance, it sounds like they approve it because they want a headache for some players? ðŸ˜† It's fine but it sounds odd andâ€¦ evil? ðŸ˜› (I mean no offence there.)

Just explaining my thoughts; I'm not asking you to do something or not to do something in the future. Please continue to enjoy what this website offers and learn along the journey!

Indeed it sounds more natural this way and the other comments I read are formulated as you say.
Mine is terse, I must admit... The meaning is just: "eventually I understand why quite often I can't get a clue"

Yeah, that would be ok.. if you really don't want to add extra test cases though, I'd add a comment to the stub generator for input [[n]] that it's always odd, you can do that by adding this below the current stub generator text:

read N:int
loop N write grid_row

INPUT
N: n is always odd

I tried to add a test case, and now I remember why I set the constraints as Nâ‰¤15, it's because the output box can't fit a 17x17 grid LMAO. So I literally can't add another test and validator (except 13).

Good idea with the stub generator. I've made the suggested change.
Thanks for your reply. It's great to hear that, as I was worried I had done something wrong.
